review.title: A Nonlinear Adaptive Filter Based on the Model of Simple Multilinear Functionals
review.abstract: Nonlinear adaptive filtering allows for modeling of some additional aspects of a general system and usually relies on highly complex algorithms, such as those based on the Volterra series. Through the use of the Kronecker product and some basic facts of tensor algebra, we propose a simple model of nonlinearity, one that can be interpreted as a product of the outputs of K FIR linear filters, and compute its cost function together with its gradient, which allows for some analysis of the optimization problem. We use these results it in a stochastic gradient framework, from which we derive an LMS-like algorithm and investigate the problems of multi-modality in the mean-square error surface and the choice of adequate initial conditions. Its computational complexity is calculated. The new algorithm is tested in a system identification setup and is compared with other polynomial algorithms from the literature, presenting favorable convergence and/or computational complexity.

sections.heading: V. SIMULATIONS
sections.text: A set of two simulations, cases I and II, were performed on the problem of system identification, with K = 2 and M = 10. Signal d (i) was an SML system plus additive zeromean Gaussian noise with variance σ2n (see (16)). The input signal was drawn from a zero-mean Gaussian distribution with uniform variance, collected in the ui − − − vector with a delayed line structure. In case I, we chose 2 − 3 and in case II, σ2n = 10 − 6. In each case, the algorithm variance was executed with uniform variance.

sections.heading: VI. DISCUSSION
sections.text: Cases I and II clearly show that the system converges to an EMSE of about − 40 dB and − 70 dB, respectively. On both sides of Fig. 2a and 2b, we can see that the SML-LMS runs slower through the first 500 iterations, then accelerates and catches up with the others - and eventually overtakes them. Both the Volterra and Wiener models assume O (M + K − 1K) operations per iteration, while the SML algorithm is only O (KM + K2). Although it is natural that the SML algorithm is better at identifying SML plants, it does so faster and with far fewer arithmetic operations. Note that the SML algorithm represents a richer dynamic than the other algorithms - something that will be examined in subsequent publications. Case III, in Fig. 2c, shows that its behavior does not just depend on the statistics of the regsor.

sections.heading: VII. CONCLUSION
sections.text: By using a Kronecker representation, we have developed the cost function for the SML model, from which the gradient was derived, which motivates a new non-linear adaptive LMS-like algorithm. It has very low computational complexity - an exponential decrease compared to the Volterra series - and competitive mean square performance in a variety of cases, but also some other unusual behaviors. Finally, the SML algorithm, like the Parallel Cascade Filter [15], enables the extension of higher-ranking models. This path will be followed in future publications.
